item.title: Declarativism
item.description: All declarative sentences should be put in a box, i.e. given a uniform semantics. Furthermore, this semantics should be that they should be thought of as “fact-stating”, a paradigm example being “the frog is on the log”.

item.title: Descriptivism
item.description: Descriptivism is a semantic theory: the belief that what you do with language is describe things. It was an improvement in the philosophy of language which allowed us to avoid the Hesperus Phosphorus puzzle.

item.title: Emotivism
item.description: How can we, in our modern scientific world, come to know moral facts? This is a problem of moral skepticism.

item.title: Empiricism
item.description: Often contrasted with rationalism and naturalism.

item.title: Expressivism
item.description: Expressivism is a broad family of views claiming some areas of discourse are ‘in the business’ of giving expression to sentiments / commitments / non-cognitive or non-representational mental states or attitudes.

item.title: Functionalism
item.description: In the philosophy of mind, … In semantics, this means that the meaning of a word is the role it plays in inferential reason relations.

item.title: Instrumentalism
item.description: All of our evidence in science comes from empirical observation, so all of our concepts (and claims) must be translatable without remainder into observational vocabulary.

item.title: Naturalism
item.description: Advanced by Huw Price’s distinction of Object naturalism and subjective naturalism.
